content.description: Stand start with a left hand, triangular crimp, and a right hand, one finger bump.  From there, work straight up the slab to a solid topout.  A high right foot on a small edge is the key to this one. The rail out left is off for this problem.
content.protection: A few pads, the landing is very good.
content.location: This is on the East face of Lavoe Boulder.

content.description: Start on the far left side on the obvious rail.... climb up and slightly to the right - a nice warm up.
content.location: On Lavoe Boulder... opposite side of the road... downclimb or jump down....

content.description: Sit from a pair of jugs below the overhang at the arete, from there work up and traverse left from the crimps around the overhang and up the slab.
content.location:
This is on Lavoe Boulder's north face, and it uses the same start as the

Aguanile

problem.

content.description: Sit start with a high left hand edge and an incut right hand crimp. From there, pull up to the shelf (crux?), traverse right along the shelf, gain the bumps on the slab, make a big move to the arete with the right hand (crux?), stand up on the left foot, and top it out.
content.protection: A pad or two should do it, the landing is perfect.
content.location:
It ascends the north face of Lavoe Rock. It shares the same start as

Baila al Ritmo

.

content.description:
Sit start below the shelf's left end with a left hand on a three finger, broken edge and a right hand in a shallow, three finger pocket.  From there, move up to the shelf and work right to a pair of crimps and stretch a right heel hook onto the arete, cross under the larger right hand crimp to an undercling with a left hand, and finish straight up and over to top it out (same finish as the

Aguanile

problem).

It is a great problem, as it requires a fair amount of body tension, and it sustains its intensity from start to finish.
content.protection: Pad or two, great landing though.
content.location: This is on the North face of the Lavoe Boulder.

content.description:
Sit start with a left hand on a triangular jug and a right hand on the arete's jug. From there, make a big move to a left hand crimp, follow with a right to a jug on the arete, then work the bumps, get a high foot and top it out.

The topout is a bit tricky and is probably the crux of the problem.
content.location: This is on the North face of the Lavoe Boulder.
